description.narrative: Pakistan Snow Leopard and Ecosystem Protection Program utilizes landscape approach for conservation and management of habitat of endangered species including Snow Leopard

activity-description.narrative: Conservation of snow leopard habitat in the target areas
Protection of niche of Snow Leopard
The activities will be done to conserve habitat of Snow leopard

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1 Extent to which institutional frameworks are implaced for integration of conservation, Sustainable Natural Resource use, controlling management of wildlife crime and illegal wildlife trade and improved livelihoods into landscape planning and management 1.2. Area of snow leopard habitat under integrated landscapes management 1.3 Status of snow leopard and associated endangered species populations in the landscapes [Scale 1 Low (0-1%), Scale 2 Medium (2-5%), Scale 3 High (6-8%) and Scale 4 Very high (8-10%) 1.4: Level of institutional capacity of provincial government agencies for planning, implementation and monitoring integrated landscape plans as measured by UNDP capacity development scorecard [Scale 1- Low (0-25%), Scale 2 Medium (26-50%), Scale 3 High (>50%)] 2.1 Effectiveness in management of protected areas within landscape as measured by Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool 2.2 Number of management and financing plans for protected areas with adequate financial resources developed and approved by Provincial government 2.3 Number of forest and wildlife staff and community members actively engaged in wildlife crime monitoring and surveillance to reduce incidence of wildlife crime 3.1 Number of Valley conservation plans developed and under implementation 3.2: Average increase in income of communities from Sustainable livelihood and resource management activities Scale 1: Less than 10,000 PKR, Scale 2: More than 10,000 PKR 3.3 Decrease incidences of human-wildlife conflict as indicated by:(i) Reduce incidence of retaliatory killing of snow leopard and other predators 4.1 Increase in the level of awareness of communities in the target landscapes on conservation and sustainable use and threats to snow leopard and biodiversity [Scale: 1= Not adequately (up to 25%); 2= Very partially (26%-50%); 3= Partially (51%-75%); 4= Largely (75%-100%)] 4.2: Number of knowledge products reflecting best practices and lessons learnt documented, disseminated and up sca

comment.narrative: 1.1 Scale 1 1.2. Scale 1 (10,000 [hectares currently managed effectively in protected areas]) 1.3 Scale 1 {200 [Snow leopard population estimate at + 200 individuals in Northern Pakistan with associated species baselines as: Karakoram-Pamir LS:, Himalayan Ibex-4,900; Markhor -230; Blue Sheep – 750; Ladakh Urial -50, Hindu Kush LS: Markhor – 3,400, Himalaya LS: Musk Deer, Brown bear} 1.4: Scale 1 [Limited institutional capacities for planning, implementation and monitoring of multiple use landscape as indicated by the capacity development baseline scores for: (i) National level-18; (ii) GB -18; (iii) AJK- 15 (iv) KP - 18] 2.1 3,100,000 [ hectares of snow leopard areas under existing PA network (national parks, sanctuaries, game reserves and community managed conservation areas, but with exception of around 10,000 ha under National Parks and/or CMCAs, other areas lack appropriate management] 2.2: 4 Management plans approved but lack adequate budgetary provisions 2.3 0 [Limited and uncoordinated training programs currently implemented and incidents of wildlife crime in landscapes] 2.3.b:136 3.1 0 [Lack of integrated landscape planning approaches and the current planning process is mostly at sectoral level] 3.2 Scale 1 3.3: Scale 1[8-10Number of incidents of retaliatory killings of snow leopard and other predators to be assessed in Year 1] 4.1 0 4.2 0 4.3:[No concerted efforts at trans-boundary and inter-provincial collaboration exists]

1.1: Scale 1 [No target for 2019] 1.2: 1 [Develop one landscape management plan for Karakorum Pamir landscape] 1.3: Scale 1 [Validate Snow leopard (4 valleys) and associated species (16 valleys) baseline show stable or improving population trends and 500 households are directly benefitting from improved livelihood incomes, At least 500 households are directly benefiting from improved sustainable grazing management and diversified and alternative livelihoods and incomes] 1.4: Multiple use landscape frameworks agreed with key stakeholders and functioning 2.1: 100,000 [hectares of additional priority snow leopard habitat including 2000 hectares of high conservation value forests to be defined legally and included in PA network] 2.2: 5 [Guidelines for improved management of CMCAs developed and approved by government and at least 5 additional management and financing plans agreed with local communities] 2.3: 40 [30 forest and wildlife officials are trained and 10 community members are actively engaged in wildlife crime monitoring and surveillance] 2.3b: 2 {Average increase by 2 points in METT from baseline] 3.1: 12 [At least 12 valley conservation plans developed and approved] 3.2: 0 (At least 2% increase in sustainable income of community) 3.3: Scale [12% decrease in livestock lost and 5% decrease in retaliatory killings of snow leopard and other predators] 4.1: Scale 1 (At least 10% of participating households (include at least 20% women beneficiaries) have good awareness of conservation, sustainable natural resource use and wildlife crime prevention benefits) 4.2: 2 [Best practice and lessons identified and at least 2 under documentation] 4.3: 1 [Initiate and negotiate at least one effective collaborative interprovincial agreement]

1.1: Scale 1 [No target for this indicator in 2019] 1.2: 1 [Landscape Management Plan of Karakorum Pamir covering 3,824,500 hectares was drafted] 1.3: Scale 1[Status of Snow leopard (3 valleys) and associated species (13 valleys) were assessed in the project landscape,14,831 [households benefitted from strengthened livelihood through solutions for improved management of natural resources including livestock vaccination, livestock insurance schemes, ecotourism etc.] 1.4: Landscape Coordination Committees (LCC) for PSLEP were constituted for 88% of its project valleys in Gilgit Baltistan (GB) and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) province. First meeting of LCC-GB was held on 25th June 2019. 2.1: 2 [Average increase by 2 points in METT from the baseline in 7 National parks (CKNP, Broghil, Quramber, Musk deer, Khunjerab, Gumot and Chitral Gol National Park)] 2.2: 4 [Implemented the guidelines for improved management of CMCAs approved by government and drafted Management and financing plan of 4 CMCAs. ] 2.3: 44 [Engaged 33 community wildlife guards in 11 project sites for wildlife crime monitoring and surveillance] 3.1: 11 [Valley conservation plans of 11 valleys were drafted and 10 VCDPs are under implementation] 3.2: Scale 1 [Increase in income of 96 households at 11 valleys (at Scale 1: <PKR10,000 per month)] 3.3: 0 [Incidences of retaliatory killing of snow leopard in project area were not reported from the project sites during the reporting period. Reports of the livestock losses to snow leopard and other carnivores in the project sites are being collected in tandem with the livestock vaccination data and would be available by the mid of January 2020] 4.1: Scale 1 [1,600 households (10.8% participating households in the landscape) including 1,500 women were given awareness on conservation and sustainable use and threats to snow leopard and biodiversity] 4.2: 3 [Lessons learnt documented in Annual Progress report 2018 and 2019. Wrote a best practice on Snow Leopard Enterprises in SLF project areas and indicated in SLF Newsletter which was disseminated to the stakeholders Documentary on Snow Leopard Enterprise and Ecotourism in Hopper valley were also developed and disseminated among stakeholders during awareness sessions as best practices.] 4.3: 1 [Collaborated with MoCC and other stakeholders to initiate development of an inter-provincial forum for biodiversity conservation under the chairmanship of Secretary Ministry of Climate Change.]

1.1: Scale 2 [Multiple use landscape frameworks agreed with key stakeholders and under review for official approval] 1.2: 3.8 million hectares [3.8 million hectares area of Karakorum Pamir landscape managed effectively through preparation of its management plan, endorsed by the provincial government] 1.3: Scale 2 [Snow leopard population estimates validated and monitoring in 6000 sq. kms and its prey species validated and monitoring in 17 valleys showing stable or improving population trends from the population described in the baseline Snow leopard population estimate at ± 200 individuals in Northern Pakistan with associated species baselines as: Karakoram-Karakoram-Pamir LS: Himalayan Ibex-4,998; Markhor -235;Blue Sheep – 765; Ladakh Urial -51Hindu Kush LS: Markhor – 3,468] 1.4: Scale 2 [medium (11%-35%)] 2.1: 10 [increase by 10 points in METT from the given baseline] 2.2: 5 [5 management and financing plans agreed with local communities and Guidelines for improved management of CMCAs developed and approved by government] 2.3: 70 [(50 forest officials, 20 community members trained)] 3.1: 8 [8 valley conservation plans developed and approved] 3.2: 5% [5% increase in average incomes (9,450 – 10,500 PKR) from sustainable livelihoods, natural resource management and business activities] 3.3: 10% [(i) 10% decrease in livestock lost/year to wildlife (0.54 head/HH/Year), (ii) 10% decrease in retaliatory killings of snow leopard and other predators (7.2-9 per Year)] 4.1: Scale 2 [20% of participating households (20% of households include women beneficiaries) have good awareness of conservation, sustainable natural resource use and wildlife crime prevention benefits 4.2: Not planned in 2020 4.3: 1 [01 effective collaborative inter-provincial agreement initiated and negotiated]

1.1: Scale1 [Landscape Coordination Committees (LCC) for PSLEP were constituted for 88% of its project valleys in Gilgit Baltistan (GB) and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) province. First meeting of LCC was held in KP on 12 March 2020. Notification of LCC in AJ&K was pursued with the Home Dept. Project board (PSC) meeting was convened in February 2020] 1.2: 3.8 million ha [Landscape Management Plan of Karakorum Pamir covering 3,824,500 hectares was updated and being shared with the provincial stakeholders for comments; Development of Landscape Management Plans of Himalaya and Hindu Kush were awarded] 1.3: Scale 1 [Studies were awarded to University of Chitral and Haripur to assess snow leopard occupancy and abundance in the Hindu Kush Landscapes covering ~5,500km² area. Ungulate surveys were undertaken in 50 valleys of GB and KP. Different species reckoned include ibex (5,408), markhor (5,367), Marco Polo Sheep (110), and blue sheep (550)] 1.4: Scale 1 = low (0-25%) [About 150 field staff of the KP (50) and GB (100) wildlife depts were engaged in the on field trainings focusing on wild ungulates.Training in planning, implementation and monitoring of Landscape Management Plans was postponed due to COVID-19 pandemic] 2.1: 5 [Average increase by 5 points in METT from the baseline in 7 National parks (CKNP, Broghil, Quramber, Musk deer, Khunjerab, Gumot and Chitral Gol National Park)] 2.2: 5 [Five Valley Conservation and Development Plans (VCDPs) were drafted and the development of 3 VCDPs were awarded. Conservation tourism plans of Hopper, Rupal and Bagrote valleys in GB were drafted] 2.3: 50 [Equipment for the implementation of SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) were procured and training plans were developed. Trainings of the 50 wildlife and community guards in wildlife crime monitoring and surveillance is planned in GB, AJK and KP] 3.1: 5 [Valley conservation plans of 5 valleys were drafted] 3.2: 5% [5% increase in average incomes (9,450 – 10,500 PKR) from sustainable livelihoods, natural resource management and business activities] 3.3:0 [Incidences of retaliatory killing of snow leopard in project area were not reported from the project sites except one case in Hopper valley during the reporting period. Reports of the livestock losses to snow leopard and other carnivores in the project sites are being collected in tandem with the livestock vaccination data and would be available in 2021] 4.1: Scale 2 [The social mobilization team of the project interacted with the communities in 17 valleys for identification, initiation and monitoring of activities. Community learning sessions were conducted during the visits reaching ~10% of the participating households] 4.1: 3 [Documentation of Snow leopard Enterprises (SLE) as a best practice was awarded. Development of the 2nd phase of documentary on Conservation Tourism was awarded. National Strategic plan on ecological and socially responsible tourism in the snow leopard landscapes drafted and shared with the MOCC for comments. Conservation Chronicles a biannual Newsletter of SLF was developed and disseminate] 4.2: No target planned in 2020 4.3: 01 [Meetings were held with Ministry of Climate Change (MOCC), Government of Pakistan and WWF-Pakistan to develop a forum for effective inter-provincial collaboration mechanisms for monitoring and surveillance of wildlife and reduce poaching and illegal wildlife trade. Similarly, the matter was raised with the three provinces during meetings. However, this target is linked with the development of the strategy to curb IWT in the snow leopard range. The strategy is being finalized by the project and will be ready for review of the provincial wildlife departments and MOCC in the first half of 2021]

1.1: Scale 3 [high 50%-60% Multiple use landscape frameworks agreed with key stakeholders and under review for official approval] 1.2: 100,000 1.3: Scale 1 (0-1%) [Snow leopard and associated species validated and monitored in 10,000 sq. km showing stable or improving population trends compared to the baseline] 1.4: Scale 3 2.1: Increase by 10 point METT 2.2: 5 2.3: 70 [50 forest and wildlife persons trained and actively enforcing environmentally friendly management practices, 20 community members actively engaged in wildlife crime monitoring and surveillance in community battalions] 3.1: 4 [valley conservation plans developed and 10 approved] 3.2: 6% [increase in av. income from sustainable livelihoods, NRM and business activities] 3.3: 20% [10% decrease in livestock lost/year to wildlife, 10% decrease in retaliatory killings of snow leopard and other predators] 4.1: Scale 3 [26% of participatory households have good awareness of conservation, sustainable natural resource use and wildlife crime prevention benefits] 4.3: 01 [one effective collaborative inter-provincial agreement initiated and negotiated]
The project is temporarily suspended. NO targets planned as yet.
